video.title: Unity GameDev Tutorial for Beginners: Brick Breaker Game
video.description:
This beginner's Unity tutorial shows how to build a Brick Breaker Game similar to the original ones from the 80's.  We will be covering topics such as:  2D games, sprites, keyboard input, input manager, Rigidbody2D, colliders, User Interface (UI), trigger colliders, OnTriggerEnter2D, OnCollisionEnter2D, loading scenes, C# and others.

🔗Download Unity here: https://store.unity.com/

⭐️Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00) Part 1 - The Paddle
⌨️ (18:21) Part 2 - The Ball
⌨️ (49:31) Part 3 - The Bricks
⌨️ (1:16:11) Part 4 - The Score and Lives
⌨️ (1:44:50) Part 5 - Ending the Level and Game
⌨️ (2:16:30) Part 6 - Making a Powerup
⌨️ (2:39:21) Part 7 - Making Special Bricks
⌨️ (2:50:39) Part 8 - Loading Levels
⌨️ (3:23:52) Part 9 - Music and Sounds
⌨️ (3:40:30) Part 10 - High Score
⌨️ (4:06:28) Part 11 - Start Menu

This tutorial was created by Mike Page of ScriptingIsFun.com. 
🔗Check out their YouTube channel for more Unity tutorials: https://www.youtube.com/user/PageTechnology

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: Justin Anderson
topLevelComment.text:
Unity interface has changed a bit since this tutorial has been made.  So if you're having problems getting the scoreText and livesText connected to the game manager, you have probably accidentally chosen Text - Text Mesh Pro.  These are graphics, not strings or integers.

You will want to delete those

Right click canvas > UI > Legacy > Text

Use that text object instead, and you will be able to drag it to the Game Manager.  Though, the text won't look as fancy.

replies.author: Justin Anderson
replies.text:
You can duplicate multiple instances of the bricks.

Place first brick.  CtrlD, Ctrl drag.  Then hold Ctrl and click each brick so both are highlighted.  Two become four.  Four become 8.  16 should be big enough for a row.  Maybe too big.  Duplicate the row and Ctrl drag it up.

Then I copied the double brick row, moved it up, and changed the color.  Did that 3 times.

If you're having trouble finding the snap tool, it was moved by the time I did this tutorial.  Right below the game and scene tabs.

replies.author: Riyujin
replies.text: It's a bit late, just in case you never found it, I'd do it like this :  just add an AudioSource to your prefab (powerups), untick "play on awake" and set them to isTrigger on the collider. Now in a script, do a OnTriggerEnter with Destroy function (add the 2nd parameter which is a delay so that it can play the sound) right after Destroy, deactivate the meshRenderer so it seems to disapear directly but it does not destroy the powerup, do a PlayOneShot of your sound. This should work pretty well. However I hope you already found a way :)

replies.author: Gamtos Vaikas
replies.text:
Hello, I have just finished this game and the tutorial was awesome.
You can fix this problem by using same method when the ball touches the ground.
Insert these lines into gameManager.cs function UpdateNumberOfBricks() else branch.
This is the place where we invoke the loading level.

just at the beginning of the existing else, insert:

ballScript ball = FindObjectOfType<ballScript>();  // to be able to acess ballScript.cs functions from gameManager.cs                                                              
                ball.rb.velocity = Vector2.zero;
                ball.inPlay = false;

this sets ball to paddle position after each level. hope instructions are clear, and happy coding!
